description: Fiction Review #19 marked the beginning of the program’s second season on the WFMT-FM. Lefley begins the program by stating that the Fiction Review is devoted to short story and novel readings, author interviews and talks, and readings from authors and critics about the art of fiction. Fiction Review #19 reviews the information discussed in Fiction Review #1 about the art of fiction. Lefley continues his discussion on the importance of the writer’s craft and technique with a thorough examination of characterization, sensory impressions, narrative pace, point of view, and methods of introspection. Next, English critic and philosopher Sir Herbert Read gives a talk entitled “The Depths Within” about the art of fiction. In the final portion of the program, selections that explore the writer’s vision of life from Anton Chekov, William Faulkner, Thomas Mann, and James Joyce are read. Passages from letters Chekov wrote about the role of the artist are read by Professor Jacob Scher of Northwestern University. Then James Joyce reads the excerpt from his “A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man” which has come to be considered the credo of the artist as rebel. Two portions of Thomas Mann’s novel “Tonio Kröger” are read. The beginning of the novel is read by Mann in German and the conclusion of the novel is read in English by Professor Scher. Lefley concludes the program by presenting a reading by Faulkner of his own Nobel Prize acceptance speech.

description: Fiction Review #38 is a two-part series that features Robert Lefley’s interviews with Lowney Handy and members of the Handy Writers’ Colony. The Handy Writers’ Colony was founded in Marshall, Illinois by Lowney Turner Handy. The purpose of the Handy Writers’ Colony was to help young and amateur writers get a solid start in writing by emphasizing discipline and mutual respect. One of the most famous members of the Handy Writers’ Colony was James Jones, author of “From Here to Eternity.” Lefley begins the program with a brief introduction to the colony. He then introduces some of the other authors working at the Handy Writers’ Colony including William H. Duhart, Tom T. Chamales, Gerald Tesch, and Edwin Daly. Lowney Handy discusses the role of the writer, the writing process, the business of the colony, and the novels of James Jones. Later in the program, other members of the Handy Writers’ Colony discuss why they joined the colony and how it’s shaped their writing process.

description: Fiction Review #47 is a recording of Nancy Hale’s lecture, “The Autobiographical Element in Fiction.” The lecture was given at the University of Chicago. Robert Lefley begins the program by providing biographical background on Nancy Hale, including her work as an assistant editor of Vogue and Vanity Fair and her time as the first female reporter at the New York Times. In her lecture, Hale explores the relationship between the autobiographical element and the world of imagination in fiction.

description: Fiction Review #7 and #44 are devoted to the life and works of novelist James Joyce. The program was originally broadcast on December 29, 1955 and later rebroadcast on January 13, 1958 and August 30, 1960. Lefley describes the program as an attempt “to bring Joyce the man, rather than the legend, into the open, to see close-up what he was like, and to indicate something of what he was trying to do in his art.” Lefley begins by providing a brief biographical background of Joyce. The first portion of the program is a recording of a meeting of the James Joyce Society in New York City. Dr. Delmore Schwartz, poet and editor of the Irish Review, presents his views on Joyce. Irish poet Padraic Colum is an audience member who contributes to the discussion. Next, the first pages from each of Joyce’s large prose works including “Dubliners,” “A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man,” “Ulysses,” and “Finnegans Wake” are read to indicate the progression of his writing style. Finally, a recording of James Joyce himself reading the concluding portion of the Anna Livia Plurabelle episode from “Finnegans Wake” is presented.

description: Fiction Review #64 begins with Robert Lefley reading the beginning of Ralph Ellison’s “Invisible Man.” Lefley then gives some biographical background and critical reviews of Ralph Ellison. Most of the recording is a talk that Ellison gave at the University of Chicago. Ellison discusses the process of getting his first pieces published and his journey to becoming a writer. creator: Lefley, Robert, 1927-|Northwestern University (Evanston, Ill.)
description: This is Robert Lefley’s interview with Italian author Natalia Ginzburg and her husband Gabriele Baldini. Ginzburg’s work explores family relationships, politics during and after the Fascist years and World War II, and philosophy. She writes novels, short stories and essays, for which she received the Strega Prize and Bagutta Prize. Gabriele Baldini is Ginzburg’s second husband and a scholar of English literature. Her first husband, Leone Ginzburg, was arrested by the Italian police in the print shop of the newspaper “L'Italia Libera.” He was taken to the German section of the Regina Coeli prison where he was tortured. He later died there from the injuries he received. During this interview, Ginzburg discusses the Strega Prize, the use of first person point of view, symbolism, the theme of her novels, the work of young Italian writers, the legacy of Fascism in Italy, the writing process, and the role of the writer. Throughout the interview, Baldini translates for Ginzburg.

description: Fiction Review #2 is a continuation of the first Fiction Review program. The program features a recording from the New School for Social Research’s literary banquet held in New York City. The main topic of the event was the life and role of the young writer. The main speakers at the banquet were novelists John Burress, James T. Farrell, Millen Brand, and philosopher/psychologist Horace M. Kallen. Essays by Katherine Anne Porter and Pearl Buck that focus on how talent develops are read by Lefley. Before each talk is presented, Lefley provides a brief biography of each speaker. Lefley begins the program by sharing some background about the New School for Social Research and the growth of writer’s workshop. Lefley gives the reading of Katherine Anne Porter’s essay, “No Masters or Teachers.” The first speaker at the banquet is author John Burress who speaks about the difficulty he had getting his first novel, “Little Mule” published. Chicago author James T. Farrell speaks next about the struggles of a young writer. Millen Brand then discusses the importance of the editing and revision process and his own thoughts on writing from the unconscious. The program concludes with an essay and a talk that discuss creative energy and what it demands of the writer. Lefley reads an essay written by Pearl Buck entitled “Creative Energy Pushes Us From Within.” The final talk at the literary banquet is given by Horace M. Kallen and he discusses the role of the writer. Part One is Lefley’s introduction through James T. Farrell’s talk. Part Two begins with Brand’s talk and concludes with Horace M. Kallen’s talk. Part Three is a partial recording of some the speakers featured in Fiction Review #2. The content begins around 11 minutes with the end of James T. Farrell’s talk. The remainder of the literary banquet is heard without Lefley’s comments. The reel was labeled “1st Take.”

description: This is the first program of the Fiction Review. Lefley describes it as being both a prospectus and manifesto. In the introduction to the program, Lefley explains that the Fiction Review will be devoted to short story readings, interviews with authors of serious fiction, and readings from authors and critics on the art of fiction writing. Lefley then previews some upcoming episodes including interviews with seven young American novelists. For the manifesto section of the program, Lefley discusses the basis on which short stories will be selected or what Lefley refers to as “the Art of Fiction.” Finally, excerpts from four of the world’s great modern writers: Anton Chekov, William Faulkner, Thomas Mann, and James Joyce are presented. Part One is the original opening of The Fiction Review from 1954. The readings from Mann, Joyce, Faulkner, and Chekov are not included. Part Two is the rebroadcast of Fiction Review #1 from May 16, 1961 and has been slightly revised. Part Two includes readings by Chekov on the life of the artist. Then James Joyce reads the excerpt from “A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man” which has come to be considered the credo of the artist as rebel. Two portions of Thomas Mann’s novel “Tonio Kröger” are read. The beginning of the novel is read by Mann in German and the conclusion of the novel is read in English by Professor Jacob Scher of Northwestern University. Scher also reads the address that William Faulkner gave when he received the National Book Award for “A Fable.” Lefley concludes the program by presenting a reading by Faulkner of his own Nobel Prize acceptance speech.

description: Fiction Review #53 explores the “most talked of literary phenomenon of the postwar years: the angry, young men of England.” The program begins with Lefley recounting an altercation between a group of young British authors including Christopher Logue, Kenneth Tynan, Michael Hastings, and Colin Wilson. Lefley then introduces Fiction Review #53’s featured speaker, Alan Pryce-Jones. Lefley feels that Jones is uniquely able to speak on the topic of England’s angry, young men because of Jones’s work as the editor of the London Times’s “Literary Supplement” and his own literary publications. Recorded at the University of Chicago, Jones gives a talk entitled “The Angry Young Men of England: English Literature in the 1950s,” in which Jones attempts to explain “who they are and why they are and if they are angry.”

description: Fiction Review #31 was taped on March 1, 1957 and features an interview with American novelist Meyer Levin. Lefley begins the program by providing a brief biographical background of Levin and a detailed description of his literary catalog and accomplishments. During the interview, Meyer and Lefley discuss Meyer’s book “Compulsion,” which Meyer called a documentary novel. “Compulsion” introduces the fictionalized case of Leopold and Loeb, once considered the "crime of the century.” This psychological portrait of two young murderers seized the imagination of an era and is generally recognized as paving the way for the first non-fiction novel. The term was later used for Truman Capote's “In Cold Blood” and Norman Mailer's “The Executioner's Song.” Meyer also speak about the role of the writer, the purpose of the novel, the disappearing line between fiction and nonfiction, the role of structure and suspense, and Meyer’s work documenting the realities of the Holocaust.

description: Fiction Review #13 features interviews with two female novelists, Helen Upshaw and Sigrid de Lima. Lefley presents the two interviews together to provide an opportunity to analyze the similarities and differences between two emerging novelists. Part One is Lefley’s interview with Upshaw. Before the interview, Lefley provides a brief biography of Upshaw. During the interview, Upshaw discusses her upbringing in the South, the writing process, character development, the role of the writer, and her first novel, “Day of the Harvest.” Part Two begins with the conclusion to the interview with Helen Upshaw. Upshaw reads a portion of a recent sketch she wrote called “My Brother’s Voice.” The rest of Part Two is Lefley’s interview with Sigrid de Lima. Lefley begins by providing brief biographical background on de Lima. In the interview de Lima discusses her decision to become a writer, the writing process, the role of the writer, her methods of writing, her inspirations for writing, and the theme of loneliness in her novels “The Captain’s Beach” and “The Swift Cloud.” The program concludes with de Lima reading the first section of her novel “The Captain’s Beach.”

description: Fiction Review #28 is Robert Lefley’s interview with novelist Mark Kennedy. At the time of this interview, Kennedy had written “The Pecking Order” and was working on his second novel, tentatively called, “The Other Side of the Moon.” In this interview, Kennedy and Lefley discuss both novels. Kennedy discusses the development of “The Pecking Order” from a short story to a novel and how the character’s goals drive the story. Kennedy talks about the characters in the novel, the research he conducted, the time frame, and the biographical elements of the novel.
